title: 108_s2584
content: The Act titled "Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004" provides a credit for farmer investment in value-added agricultural property under section 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 offers a 50% credit for eligible persons or farmer-owned entities on the basis of qualified value-added agricultural property placed in service during the taxable year. The credit is allocated among eligible persons in a farmer-owned entity on a pro rata basis. The Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 provides a 50% credit for eligible persons or farmer-owned entities based on qualified agricultural property placed in service during the taxable year. The credit is allocated among eligible persons in a farmer-owned entity on a pro rata basis, with a maximum credit limit of $30,000 for property placed in service by an eligible person. The credit for property placed in service by an eligible person or farmer-owned entity under the Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 is limited to $30,000, reduced by creditable investments. For property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity, the credit cannot exceed the sum of the eligible person's investments in the entity. The credit for property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity is limited to the eligible person's creditable investments in the entity. Creditable investments refer to the qualified investments made by the eligible person in the entity. The term 'creditable investments' refers to the qualified investments made by an eligible person in a farmer-owned entity, which are used to determine the credit for property placed in service. The term 'creditable investments' are reduced by the sum of qualified investments made by the person in the entity and other farmer-owned entities for property previously placed in service. The eligible person's qualified investments in farmer-owned entities for property previously placed in service are limited to $30,000 per taxable year. The eligible person's qualified investments in farmer-owned entities for property previously placed in service are limited to $30,000 per taxable year. Qualified value-added agricultural property refers to property used to add value to goods or products suitable for food or nonfood use. Qualified value-added agricultural property is defined as property used to add value to goods derived from organic matter, including agricultural crops, wastes, wood residues, and animal wastes, and is eligible for tax benefits under section 168.
